references: In this section, we first describe an FL system model and the corresponding threat model used in this paper, and then identify our design goals. Before describing in detail, we would like to give the description of the notations used in the proposed scheme in Table I.

references:
In this section, we list the comparison of the privacy and fault tolerance for the state-of-the-art secure aggregation schemes in Table II, where âœ“and âœ• denote satisfied and unsatisfied, respectively. Before discussing the comparison result, we would like to briefly introduce these five schemes. Specifically, the schemes [14] and [30] are designed by the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique, while both the scheme [8] and our scheme are presented based on the additive homomorphic encryption technique. The scheme [32] is introduced by combining these two techniques, where the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique and the additive homomorphic encryption technique are used for private key distribution and secure additive aggregation, respectively.
First of all, since the main purpose of secure aggregation in federated learning is to protect the local gradient, all schemes naturally meet the confidentiality of individual clients.
